awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Collaborative Research: Deep learning enhanced parallel computations of fluid flow around moving boundaries on binarized octrees
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer simulations of heat and fluid flow find applications in many aspects of science and engineering. Notable examples are aerodynamic design of aircrafts and automobiles, and weather forecasting. These simulations are often computationally expensive, and they are performed on supercomputers. Special methods are used to implement the equations of heat and fluid flow as a simulation software. The end goal is to create an accurate computer code that can make optimal use of available computing power. However, this end goal is becoming challenging on modern extreme-scale supercomputers that deploy a large of number of computing processors to work in parallel. Existing algorithms face performance bottlenecks and do not realize the full potential of a modern supercomputer. The project team will develop new algorithms to overcome this performance bottleneck. The successful completion of this award is expected to result in an open-source heat and fluid flow simulation software. The project team will develop educational tutorials to pique the interest of high-school students in new capabilities of computer simulation and machine learning techniques in science and engineering. 

The technical objective is to enhance parallel performance of simulations of incompressible fluid flow around moving boundaries. A recently developed binarized octree generation technique will be further developed as an open-source parallel adaptive mesh refinement software infrastructure to solve the fluid flow equations on Cartesian domains with deep levels of mesh adaptations. Machine learning techniques and deep neural nets will be adopted in ways to ease potential bottlenecks that are expected to degrade scalability of parallel computations when large number of processors are deployed in simulations. The project team will develop multiple deep learning algorithms such as convolutional neural networks and generative adversarial networks to learn the fluid flow around complex geometries and apply the learning for rapid and accurate field estimation at arbitrary points. To successfully incorporate the effect of boundary conditions at the interface, conditional generative adversarial networks will be trained on different coarse and fine grids to learn the communication pattern among the blocks. 

This award by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems within the NSF Directorate of Engineering is jointly supported by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research project set out to enhance the parallel performance of simulations involving incompressible fluid flow around moving boundaries using modern supercomputers. We aimed to leverage advanced machine learning (ML) techniques and deep neural networks (DNNs) to improve the efficiency and scalability of adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) applications. This involved developing a novel parallel AMR software infrastructure, integrating deep learning algorithms to optimize computational processes, and addressing the scalability challenges associated with large-scale parallel computations.


Intellectual Merit:

The core intellectual contribution of our project lies in the innovative integration of ML and DNNs into high-fidelity fluid dynamics simulations. Traditional applications of ML in computational transport phenomena have been limited, especially for complex problems typically addressed using sophisticated numerical methods. Our approach has pushed the boundaries by:

1. Enhancing AMR Techniques: We developed a binarized octree generation technique to refine the AMR process, significantly improving the parallel scalability of fluid flow simulations.

2. Machine Learning Integration: Various ML models, including Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), were employed to predict fluid flow dynamics and accelerate computational processes. Conditional GANs were particularly effective in learning communication patterns among grid blocks, reducing the computational overhead associated with collective communications.

3. Domain Decomposition for Poisson’s Equation: Deep learning methods were implemented as standalone domain decomposition strategies to solve the elliptic Poisson’s equation in parallel, a critical and computationally intensive component of incompressible flow solvers. This approach not only improved solution accuracy but also enhanced convergence rates significantly.


 Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of our project extend across multiple dimensions:


1. Open-Source Software Development: We developed and released an open-source AMR software package, facilitating further research and innovation in computational fluid dynamics (CFD). This software provides a robust platform for other researchers to build upon, promoting advancements in various scientific and engineering domains

.2. Educational Contributions: We integrated our research findings into academic curricula at the University of Pittsburgh (Pitt) and Carnegie Mellon University (CMU). Courses on parallel computing and machine learning were enriched with new content, including guest lectures and practical projects on using ML for transport phenomena. These educational efforts have prepared a new generation of engineers and scientists with cutting-edge skills in ML and HPC (high-performance computing).

3. Outreach and Diversity: We created ML tutorials as interactive Jupyter notebooks aimed at high school students and underrepresented groups. These tutorials, showcased at outreach events and summer schools, aimed to spark interest in STEM careers by demonstrating the power and potential of ML and DL (deep learning) in solving real-world engineering problems  .

Project Outcomes

Over the project's lifespan, we achieved several key outcomes:


1. Improved Computational Efficiency: The integration of deep learning techniques into our AMR infrastructure resulted in substantial improvements in computational efficiency. For instance, the cGAN and Transformer models demonstrated significant speedups in solving heat conduction problems compared to traditional finite difference methods, without compromising accuracy.

2. Enhanced Parallel Performance: Our deep learning-assisted domain decomposition methods maintained high parallel efficiency, even when scaling to thousands of GPUs. This was validated through extensive testing on supercomputers, showcasing the robustness and scalability of our approach .

3. Research Dissemination: The project led to several high-impact publications and conference presentations, disseminating our findings to the broader scientific community. These scholarly contributions have sparked interest and further research in the intersection of ML and CFD.


In summary, our project has made significant strides in advancing the field of computational fluid dynamics through the innovative application of machine learning. The intellectual and broader impacts of our work underscore its potential to transform not only how we simulate and understand fluid flow but also how future engineers and scientists are trained and inspired  .
